title: Unlingen
text:
Unlingen () is a town in the district of <a href="Biberach%20%28district%29">Biberach</a> in <a href="Baden-W%C3%BCrttemberg">Baden-Württemberg</a> in <a href="Germany">Germany</a>.
Geography.
Unlingen lies in southwestern Germany, between the Upper Swabian mountain known as the <a href="Bussen">Bussen</a> and the river <a href="Danube">Danube</a>.
Unlingen contains the districts of Dietelhofen, Göffingen, Möhringen and Uigendorf.
Political history.
The first recorded mention of Unlingen occurred in 1163. In 1291 Unlingen fell to the House of <a href="Habsburg">Habsburg</a>, and eventually became a part of <a href="Further%20Austria">Further Austria</a>. At the end of the 14th century, the Steward of <a href="House%20of%20Waldburg">Waldburg</a> held large portions of the town. In 1525, 2,000 farmers gathered in Unlingen as it became one of the starting points of the <a href="German%20Peasants%27%20War">German Peasants' War</a>. During the <a href="Thirty%20Years%27%20War">Thirty Years' War</a>, Unlingen was destroyed by both Imperial and Swedish troops. In 1635, plague killed a large part of the population.
In 1806, during the <a href="Napoleonic%20Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a>, Unlingen became a part of the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20W%C3%BCrttemberg">Kingdom of Württemberg</a> and was assigned to the jurisdiction of <a href="Riedlingen">Riedlingen</a>. With the district reform of 1938, the town became part of the county of <a href="Saulgau">Saulgau</a>, then in 1973 was added to the district of <a href="Biberach%20%28district%29">Biberach</a>.
Religious history.
By 1269 a church stood in Unlingen. In 1414 the Franciscan monastery "Maria Heimsuchung" was founded.
Notable residents.
<a href="Germany">German</a> <a href="Striker%20%28association%20football%29">striker</a> <a href="Mario%20Gomez">Mario Gomez</a> grew up in Unlingen.
